perseuspy.io package¶

Submodules¶

perseuspy.io.maxquant module¶

utility functions for parsing various generic output tables of MaxQuant/Perseus

perseuspy.io.maxquant.read_experimentalDesign(filename)[source]¶

parse the ‘experimentalDesign.txt’ file into a pandas dataframe

perseuspy.io.perseus module¶

class perseuspy.io.perseus.PathOrFile(path_or_file, mode=None, reset=False)[source]¶

Bases: object

Small context manager for file paths or file-like objects :param path_or_file: Path to a file or file-like object :param mode: Set reading/writing mode :param reset: Reset file-like to initial position. Has no effect on path.

perseuspy.io.perseus.create_column_index(annotations)[source]¶

Create a pd.MultiIndex using the column names and any categorical rows. Note that also non-main columns will be assigned a default category ‘’.

perseuspy.io.perseus.read_annotations(path_or_file, separator, type_map={'M': <class 'str'>, 'N': <class 'float'>, 'E': <class 'float'>, 'C': 'category', 'T': <class 'str'>}, reset=True)[source]¶

Read all annotations from the specified file.

>>> annotations = read_annotations(path_or_file, separator)
>>> colnames = annotations['Column Name']
>>> types = annotations['Type']
>>> annot_row = annotations['Annot. row name']
Parameters:
  • path_or_file – Path or file-like object
  • separator – Column separator
  • type_map – Mapping Perseus types to numpy.dtype
  • reset – Reset the file after reading. Useful for file-like, no-op for paths.
Returns:

Ordered dictionary of annotations.
perseuspy.io.perseus.read_perseus(path_or_file, type_map={'M': <class 'str'>, 'N': <class 'float'>, 'E': <class 'float'>, 'C': 'category', 'T': <class 'str'>}, **kwargs)[source]¶

Read a Perseus-formatted matrix into a pd.DataFrame. Annotation rows will be converted into a multi-index.

By monkey-patching the returned pd.DataFrame a to_perseus method for exporting the pd.DataFrame is made available.

Parameters:
  • path_or_file – File path or file-like object
  • type_map – How to map Perseus types to numpy.dtype
  • **kwargs –

    Keyword arguments passed as-is to pandas.read_csv
Returns:

The parsed data frame
perseuspy.io.perseus.to_perseus(df, path_or_file, main_columns=None, separator='\t', type_map={dtype('O'): 'T', dtype('<U'): 'T', dtype('float64'): 'N', dtype('int64'): 'N', category: 'C'}, numerical_annotation_rows=set())[source]¶

Save pd.DataFrame to Perseus text format.

Parameters:
  • df – pd.DataFrame
  • path_or_file – File name or file-like object
  • main_columns – Main columns. Will be infered if set to None. All numeric columns up-until the first non-numeric column are considered main columns.
  • separator – For separating fields, default ‘ ‘

perseuspy.io.perseusNetwork module¶

perseuspy.io.perseusNetwork.add_node(allDicts, nodeName, networkid)[source]¶

This function adds a node to the Graph and corresponding nodeTable. Note: Adding a existing node, will lead to duplicate rows in nodeTable but no change in the corresponding graph!

Parameters:
  • allDicts – List of [networkTable, networkNodes, networkEdges, networkNameGUID, networkGraph]
  • nodeName – Name of the node to be added
  • networkid – GUID of the network the node will be added to
Returns:

List of [networkTable, networkNodes, networkEdges, networkNameGUID, networkGraph]
perseuspy.io.perseusNetwork.print_network_names(networkTable)[source]¶

Printing all network names.

Parameters:networkTable – Pandas data frame containing overview of the networks
perseuspy.io.perseusNetwork.read_networks(pathInFolder)[source]¶

Translating networks and corresponding node-/ and edgeTables to graphs

>>> allDicts = read_networks(pathinFolder)
Parameters:pathInFolder – Path to directory
Returns:List of [networkTable, networkNodes, networkEdges, networkNameGUID, networkGraph]
perseuspy.io.perseusNetwork.write_networks(pathOutFolder, allDicts)[source]¶

Writing networkTable, networkNodes and networkEdges to Perseus readable format

Important when changing graphs: As ‘writeNetworks(...)’ currently writes the networks from networkTable, networkNodes and networkEdges (not from networkGraph!), networkGraph shall represent the same graphs as networkTable, networkNodes and networkEdges imply. To keep this relation: When changing graph, simultaneously changing networkTables(network). -> For example add_edge(), add_node(), remove_edge(), remove_node() necessary.

Parameters:
  • pathOutFolder – Path to directory
  • allDicts – List of minimum networkTable, networkNodes and networkEdges
